docs.snippet: The United States team is tired.  It's not a question of fitness -- the strength and conditioning coach Pierre Barrieu has been praised by the coach and players all week.  But there is a sort of fatigue setting in.     ''We get tired of kicking each...
docs.lead_paragraph: The United States team is tired. It's not a question of fitness -- the strength and conditioning coach Pierre Barrieu has been praised by the coach and players all week. But there is a sort of fatigue setting in. ''We get tired of kicking each other, we get tired of training, we get tired,'' goalkeeper Tim Howard said Thursday. ''We're together for like forever.''
docs.abstract: US soccer team players prefer to stop talking about opening match against England and play World Cup game (S)

headline.main: Americans Declare It's Time To Play Ball

headline.main: Friday's Matchups: Mexico vs. South Africa and France vs. Uruguay

docs.snippet: Live analysis and matchtracking of the opening game of the 2010 World Cup between South Africa and Mexico.
docs.lead_paragraph: South Africa opened the first World Cup in Africa with a 1-1 tie against Mexico in Johannesburg on Friday, weathering early nerves, scoring the tournament's first goal and hitting the post with a potential winning shot in the 90th minute.
docs.abstract: Live analysis and matchtracking of the opening game of the 2010 World Cup between South Africa and Mexico.

headline.main: Mexico Escapes With a Tie Against South Africa

docs.snippet: Live analysis of the second game of the 2010 World Cup: Uruguay versus France.
docs.lead_paragraph: After the first day of the 2010 World Cup and all the pomp and circumstance, there was nothing that sorted out the direction that Group A will take with both games ending in draws.  Uruguay, an underdog like South Africa was when it faced Mexico, is no doubt feeling better after playing to a scoreless draw with France.
docs.abstract: Live analysis of the second game of the 2010 World Cup: Uruguay versus France.

docs.snippet: The Yankees' clubhouse gets excited about its World Cup pool.
docs.lead_paragraph: The Yankees on Friday turned their attention to the beautiful game. And no, that is not a reference to Stephen Strasburg's 14-strikeout debut on Tuesday, but rather to the World Cup.
docs.abstract: The Yankees' clubhouse gets excited about its World Cup pool.

docs.snippet: An uncalled hand ball by Thierry Henry last November helped France qualify for the World Cup, so it was a bit rich to see Henry imploring the referee to call a hand ball against Uruguay.
